passage:
(1) The Age of Imperialism, spanning roughly from the late 19th to the early 20th century, marked an unprecedented period of European expansion across Africa, Asia, and the Pacific. This era was characterized by the rapid acquisition of territories by powerful nations seeking to extend their political influence, economic resources, and cultural dominance. The technological advancements following the Industrial Revolution—including steamships, railways, and telegraph communications—provided European powers with unprecedented capabilities to project military force and administrative control over distant regions, fundamentally altering the global balance of power.

(2) Economic motivations served as primary drivers of imperial expansion. The quest for raw materials to fuel growing industries, new markets for manufactured goods, and profitable investment opportunities pushed nations to establish colonial holdings. Western powers implemented extractive economic policies designed to benefit the metropole rather than foster local development. Indigenous economies were often restructured to focus on cash crops or resource extraction, disrupting traditional livelihoods and creating economic dependencies that would persist long after formal colonial rule ended. These economic transformations introduced new commodities to global markets while simultaneously creating vulnerability in colonial economies tied to fluctuating international prices.

(3) The social and cultural dimensions of imperialism proved equally transformative. Colonial administrators sought to classify indigenous populations according to Western taxonomies and imposed governance systems that frequently undermined traditional authority structures. Missionary activities, educational policies, and administrative practices exposed local populations to European values, languages, and social organizations. This cultural imperialism created complex dynamics of assimilation, resistance, and hybridization as colonized peoples navigated between preserving cultural identities and adapting to new realities. The ambitious project of

non-Western peoples often masked exploitation behind rhetoric of progress and development.

(4) Resistance to imperial domination took various forms across different regions and periods. Some societies mounted sophisticated military resistance, while others engaged in passive non-cooperation, strategic accommodation, or intellectual critique of colonial ideologies. Anti-colonial movements gradually evolved from localized protests to organized nationalist campaigns advocating for self-determination and equality. Indigenous leaders often appropriated Western concepts of nationalism, democracy, and human rights to challenge the legitimacy of colonial rule, demonstrating the paradoxical ways in which imperial systems contained the seeds of their own dissolution. By the mid-20th century, these movements would successfully force European powers to withdraw from most colonial possessions.

(5) The legacies of imperialism continue to shape our contemporary world in profound ways. Modern geopolitical boundaries, language distributions, legal systems, and economic relationships often reflect colonial histories. Postcolonial nations continue to grapple with institutional structures inherited from colonial periods, while global economic disparities partially trace their origins to imperial exploitation. Cultural exchanges during this period produced enduring influences in art, literature, cuisine, and social practices in both colonizing and colonized societies. The complex interplay between imperial domination and local agency remains central to understanding global history, reminding us that current international relations still unfold within contexts partially defined by this transformative era.

questions.question: Which sentence uses the present perfect tense correctly?

options.A: I live in New York since 2010.
options.B: She has gone to Paris last summer.
options.C: They have studied English for three years.
options.D: We are working here for six months.

questions.question: Choose the correct relative pronoun: 'The book _____ you recommended was excellent.'
Select the correct form of the reported speech. Direct speech: 'I am going to the store now.'

options.A: She said she is going to the store now.
options.B: She said she was going to the store then.
options.C: She said she has gone to the store now.
options.D: She said she will go to the store then.

questions.question: Which sentence contains a correct conditional form?

options.A: If I will study harder, I would pass the exam.
options.B: If I had studied harder, I will pass the exam.
options.C: If I studied harder, I would pass the exam.
options.D: If I study harder, I would pass the exam.

options.A: The cake is baking by my mother.
options.B: The report will written by tomorrow.
options.C: The house was building last year.
options.D: The decision has been made by the committee.

options.C: Each of the participants was given a certificate.

options.D: By next year, she has graduated from college.

options.B: The imposition of European values and practices
options.D: The systematic documentation of global cultures
